JOTTINGS FROM A NOTE-BOOK.
The most cheerful disposition to "write
something" about a six-month spent abroad
suffers embarrassment in choice of a point of
view. Details of place and travel can hardly
be expected to interest an academic body
whose trans-Atlantic movements are periodic
and in mass. On the other hand, a description
of the status of European bimetallism, even
if escaping the inherent weakness—as has
been politely suggested—of a dissertation on
Irish snakes, has at least the inconvenience of
a class lecture out of its course. Neither of
these dangcrs threatens a series of mere personal jottings, and nothing more than this is
here attempted.
*
*
.To the student untried in public life, initial
contact with political activity and diplomatic
usage is fairly thrilling. A tyro will never forget the excitement of an unexpected cipher
message, or the tension of a delayed reply
from a foreign office. He comes to realize
that political treatises stand in the same relation to actual political life that manuals on
"how to listen to music" do to a Beethoven
sonata. He returns to his closet in chastened
spirit, writes to Washington for the Congressional Record, forms the acquaintance of the
councilmen of his ward, and proceeds thereafter to study history in the making.
*
There is nothing which incenses a moderately patriotic American when abroad to a
greater degree, than to hear—as he repeatedly
must—the phrase "shirt-sleeve diplomacy," or
some equally picturesque idiom, applied to
American international procedure. In the
light of recent events, it would be of interest
to compare the official conduct of our own and
of foreign diplomatists for a term of years.
Whatever might be the result, certainly the
present diplomatic representation of the
United -States in the leading countries of
Western Europe—General Porter in Paris,
Colonel Hay in London, and Ex-President

A.

White in Berlin—leaves little to be desired.
The unwholesome influence of party politics
upon diplomatic service appears in the uncertain tenure of the junior force of the several
embassies. But even here there is promise of
better things, and the possibility of diplomacy
as a career in the United States as in every
other civilized country, is not hopelessly
remote.
* *
No experience in Paris recurs with the same
vivid pleasure as the simple celebration of
Decoration Day at Lafayette's grave, by a
handful of Americans. We gathered one
warm May afternoon in the peaceful convent
yard of the Rue de Picpusas far removed from
the life and stir of the great city as though
leagues instead of yards intervened. Then
past the simple chapel where for a century
successive black-robed figures have knelt in
continuous adoration—up a long shaded path
to the Cimitiere des Guillotines, an enclosure
no larger than an ordinary lecture-room, with
the unmarked remains of thirteen hundred of
the noblest victims of the Revolution. Just
outside the portal lies the patriot—in immortal
protest against the excesses of the cause he
loved. We draped our flag about the plain
slab that marks the grave ; a few words were
spoken, and we sang as best we could our own
anthem. There is little sentiment in the telling ; but at least one of those present will
never forget the scene.
*
*
The one feature of English political life
which impresses him who has faithfully
gnawed the dry bones of Stubbs and May, and
still hungers, is the combination of feverish
activity and periodic relaxation. There is no
legislative body in the world which moves at a
more rapid, nerve-consuming pace than the
House of Commons ; yet woe betide the reactionists who would block the week-end
exodus to country and country-house, or endeavor to keep Parliament in session one day
after the shooting has begun! Even in London, the summer session and the social season

dines out at eight, shows himself at two receptions before ten, and is on his bench in the
House an half-hour later, if not a type, is far
from a rarity. The pictures which Mrs.

To an American the chief delight of English country house life consists in that it is
realized literature. He sees in institutional
flesh and blood the things of which he has
read all his life—and he falls utter, abject captive to their charm. The process of adaptation is not without embarrassment, and the
initial breakfast is distinctly an ordeal ; but
adjustment comes easily, and thereafter it is
the pleasure of hospitality without the burden
of entertainment. Of course it is no longer
the life of Sir Roger de Coverly, nor even of
Bracebridge Hall ; but characteristic elements
still abound and make rural residence the distinctive feature of English social life. Perhaps we too in America shall some time stop
"getting a living" and proceed to live, but the
likelihood is not immediate.

From London and diplomacy to Carlsbad
and its life is a far cry, and yet few things delight in the retrospect so much as the incidents of a brief sojourn in this old Bohemian
spa. Mr. Howell spent four weeks there last
summer, and perhaps we shall not have to
wait much longer for a Carlsbad novel.
Surely the author, whoever he is to be, will not
suffer from lack of incident and color. The
cosmopolitan clientele, the apotheosis of "the
waters," the gravity of the Kur-Gaste, the simplicity of the life, the beauty of the environment, the glory of the music—all flash upon
one in but a fraction of the second necessary
to record them. Someone has said that the
happiness of life consists in being paid for
doing that which you enjoy doing. Perhaps
a no less keen satisfaction results from doing
nothing and feeling virtuos—and this is a
characteristic of incidental Carlsbad residence.

KNOW-NOTITINOISM.

Mr. Schmeckebier read a very interesting
paper before the Historical and Political
Science Association on Friday evening, on
"The Know-Nothing Party in Maryland."
Mr. Schmeckebier traced the growth of this,
the most curious and unique of the many political organizations which have flourished in
American politics. The causes for the use of
this secret society seems to be due to the
strong anti-foreign and anti-Catholic feelings
which were prevalent at the time. Local issues all over the country gave rise to similar
expressions of these feelings, though we can
hardly say that there was ever a natural Know
Nothing party. Its forces were largely recruited by members of the then tottering and
expiring Whig party—men who were naturally unwilling to affiliate with their political
enemies, the Democrats. Opinions differ as
to the degree to which the Know Nothing
party was responsible for the rioting of the
period. Rioting had existed before the rise
of the party, but it is very evident that the excesses were carried to a much greater extent
in 1856, during the rule of the Know Nothing
party, than ever before. Very interesting extracts were read from diaries and newspapers
of the day touching upon the subject.
Mr. Schmeckebier's paper, which is the basis
of his doctor's thesis, was very highly commended, both for his treatment of the subject
and for the scholarly research evinced.

THE HOPKINS RELIEF BILL.

The relief bill still hangs in the balance at
Annapolis. When the House defeated it recently, we, for a time, lost all hope for it; but
later developments are more encouraging, and
it is still possible that Hopkins may get at least
a portion of the aid she has asked for. At any
rate, we will continue to hope.
We are of those who have great faith in the
good intentions of our country legislators. Of
course, they wish to economize, but we trust
they will realize that it is false economy to
allow so great an institution to decay for want
of temporary aid—an institution which is, in
fact, part of the honor and dignity of the State
in the eyes of all foreigners and neighbors, if
not of her own citizens. Should the Hopkins
fail for want of help at this time, no Marylander
could meet an outsider for years to come without the parsimony of his native State being
thrown in his teeth, and the Marylander would
have to take his punishment in silence. The
amount asked is about 5 cents per head for the
two years—a small sum to keep the State from
being a sneer and a byword for narrow-minded
parsimony. Some of the objections given are
what we may call personal to the Hopkins.

They may be meant in all seriousness, but
make us smile. Thus we, the students are accused of putting on "airs,' and of having too
much money. As for the first, no more surely
does he who enters Inferno leave Hope _behind
than does the newcomer at the Hopkins drop
all "airs;" that is one thing they have to shed,
even as the crab constituent of Hon. Mr. Tull
has to shed his shell, or the snake of the Hon.
Mr. Morris' district has to shed his skin to the
horny part of the eye, if he wishes to thrive.
As for the wealth, may the Hon. Gentlemen
never rise from the table as empty in pocket as
most of us at this time of year. All this shows
one thing, however—it shows that we need to
be a little better acquainted. Let some of our
Hon. Friends pay us, the students, a social call,
and let us show them around. Ask for one of
the editors of the NEWS-LETTER, and we will
make you feel at home. No, gentlemen of the
House and Senate, most of us are good looking, but we are neither haughty of stomach or
proud of purse.

MR. MACKDERMOTT'S WORK.

The rumored resignation of Mr. Mackdermott from the position of coach and director
of track athletics at the University will prove a
grievous disappointment to all the students
who have worked with him and know how invaluable his voluntary service has been, in the
past and the present, to that branch of our
athletics. The development in the past two
years of a creditable relay team has been entirely due to his efforts. To expect Mr. Mackdermott to continue his generous assistance indefinitely, without any of the recompense which
his services so well deserve, but which the University in her present financial straits cannot
give him, is beyond reason. And if he decides
to leave us on this account, no one can at all
blame him for so doing. At any rate, whether
he stays or goes, Mr. Mackdermott may feel
sure of the hearty gratitude of all the students
to him for his past good will and good deeds
toward them, and a thorough sympathy with
his present work on the track candidates.

LACROSSE.

Manager Grimes has not completed the Lacrosse schedule, but promises a good one.
Hopkins plays but two games in Baltimore—
one with Lehigh and the other with Columbia.
The championship game with Stevens is to be
played in Hoboken.
The Lacrosse candidates are showing up
well. The 'Varsity has not been selected as
yet, and some of the new men have excellent
chances for positions. The scrub will soon
be chosen, and a captain elected. Hopkins
has never learned how important it is to have
scrub teams. The scrub this year will mean
something, and games will be arranged for
the scrub.
HOCKEY SEASON'S CLOSE.

The last hockey game of the season, between Hopkins and the University of Maryland, resulted in neither team being able to
score. The players on both sides worked
hard, and put up one of the best games of the
year. Although Hopkins finished in third
place, the members of the team deserve much
credit for their good work and determination.
Several times the team was so disheartened by
the loss of some of its good players that it contemplated dropping out of the League. But
a few determined men kept together and
pulled through the season very creditably. The
defense work in the last game was beautiful.
The team deserved much more support than
it received from the students of the University.

The most cheerful disposition to "write
something" about a six-month spent abroad
suffers embarrassment in choice of a point of
view. Details of place and travel can hardly
be expected to interest an academic body
whose trans-Atlantic movements are periodic
and in mass. On the other hand, a description
of the status of European bimetallism, even
if escaping the inherent weakness—as has
been politely suggested—of a dissertation on
Irish snakes, has at least the inconvenience of
a class lecture out of its course. Neither of
these dangcrs threatens a series of mere personal jottings, and nothing more than this is
here attempted.
*
*
.To the student untried in public life, initial
contact with political activity and diplomatic
usage is fairly thrilling. A tyro will never forget the excitement of an unexpected cipher
message, or the tension of a delayed reply
from a foreign office. He comes to realize
that political treatises stand in the same relation to actual political life that manuals on
"how to listen to music" do to a Beethoven
sonata. He returns to his closet in chastened
spirit, writes to Washington for the Congressional Record, forms the acquaintance of the
councilmen of his ward, and proceeds thereafter to study history in the making.
*
There is nothing which incenses a moderately patriotic American when abroad to a
greater degree, than to hear—as he repeatedly
must—the phrase "shirt-sleeve diplomacy," or
some equally picturesque idiom, applied to
American international procedure. In the
light of recent events, it would be of interest
to compare the official conduct of our own and
of foreign diplomatists for a term of years.
Whatever might be the result, certainly the
present diplomatic representation of the
United -States in the leading countries of
Western Europe—General Porter in Paris,
Colonel Hay in London, and Ex-President

A.

No. 12

White in Berlin—leaves little to be desired.
The unwholesome influence of party politics
upon diplomatic service appears in the uncertain tenure of the junior force of the several
embassies. But even here there is promise of
better things, and the possibility of diplomacy
as a career in the United States as in every
other civilized country, is not hopelessly
remote.
* *
No experience in Paris recurs with the same
vivid pleasure as the simple celebration of
Decoration Day at Lafayette's grave, by a
handful of Americans. We gathered one
warm May afternoon in the peaceful convent
yard of the Rue de Picpusas far removed from
the life and stir of the great city as though
leagues instead of yards intervened. Then
past the simple chapel where for a century
successive black-robed figures have knelt in
continuous adoration—up a long shaded path
to the Cimitiere des Guillotines, an enclosure
no larger than an ordinary lecture-room, with
the unmarked remains of thirteen hundred of
the noblest victims of the Revolution. Just
outside the portal lies the patriot—in immortal
protest against the excesses of the cause he
loved. We draped our flag about the plain
slab that marks the grave ; a few words were
spoken, and we sang as best we could our own
anthem. There is little sentiment in the telling ; but at least one of those present will
never forget the scene.
*
*
The one feature of English political life
which impresses him who has faithfully
gnawed the dry bones of Stubbs and May, and
still hungers, is the combination of feverish
activity and periodic relaxation. There is no
legislative body in the world which moves at a
more rapid, nerve-consuming pace than the
House of Commons ; yet woe betide the reactionists who would block the week-end
exodus to country and country-house, or endeavor to keep Parliament in session one day
after the shooting has begun! Even in London, the summer session and the social season

are identical in time, and the minister who
dines out at eight, shows himself at two receptions before ten, and is on his bench in the
House an half-hour later, if not a type, is far
from a rarity. The pictures which Mrs.
Humphrey Ward has given us of the interrelation of English social and political life are,
perhaps, exaggerated ; but the error is, I
think, only one of degree.
*
*
To an American the chief delight of English country house life consists in that it is
realized literature. He sees in institutional
flesh and blood the things of which he has
read all his life—and he falls utter, abject captive to their charm. The process of adaptation is not without embarrassment, and the
initial breakfast is distinctly an ordeal ; but
adjustment comes easily, and thereafter it is
the pleasure of hospitality without the burden
of entertainment. Of course it is no longer
the life of Sir Roger de Coverly, nor even of
Bracebridge Hall ; but characteristic elements
still abound and make rural residence the distinctive feature of English social life. Perhaps we too in America shall some time stop
"getting a living" and proceed to live, but the

KNOW-NOTITINOISM.

Mr. Schmeckebier read a very interesting
paper before the Historical and Political
Science Association on Friday evening, on
"The Know-Nothing Party in Maryland."
Mr. Schmeckebier traced the growth of this,
the most curious and unique of the many political organizations which have flourished in
American politics. The causes for the use of
this secret society seems to be due to the
strong anti-foreign and anti-Catholic feelings
which were prevalent at the time. Local issues all over the country gave rise to similar
expressions of these feelings, though we can
hardly say that there was ever a natural Know
Nothing party. Its forces were largely recruited by members of the then tottering and
expiring Whig party—men who were naturally unwilling to affiliate with their political
enemies, the Democrats. Opinions differ as
to the degree to which the Know Nothing
party was responsible for the rioting of the
period. Rioting had existed before the rise
of the party, but it is very evident that the excesses were carried to a much greater extent
in 1856, during the rule of the Know Nothing
party, than ever before. Very interesting extracts were read from diaries and newspapers
of the day touching upon the subject.
Mr. Schmeckebier's paper, which is the basis
of his doctor's thesis, was very highly commended, both for his treatment of the subject
and for the scholarly research evinced.

THE HOPKINS RELIEF BILL.

The relief bill still hangs in the balance at
Annapolis. When the House defeated it recently, we, for a time, lost all hope for it; but
later developments are more encouraging, and
it is still possible that Hopkins may get at least
a portion of the aid she has asked for. At any
rate, we will continue to hope.
We are of those who have great faith in the
good intentions of our country legislators. Of
course, they wish to economize, but we trust
they will realize that it is false economy to
allow so great an institution to decay for want
of temporary aid—an institution which is, in
fact, part of the honor and dignity of the State
in the eyes of all foreigners and neighbors, if
not of her own citizens. Should the Hopkins
fail for want of help at this time, no Marylander
could meet an outsider for years to come without the parsimony of his native State being
thrown in his teeth, and the Marylander would
have to take his punishment in silence. The
amount asked is about 5 cents per head for the
two years—a small sum to keep the State from
being a sneer and a byword for narrow-minded
parsimony. Some of the objections given are
what we may call personal to the Hopkins.

They may be meant in all seriousness, but
make us smile. Thus we, the students are accused of putting on "airs,' and of having too
much money. As for the first, no more surely
does he who enters Inferno leave Hope _behind
than does the newcomer at the Hopkins drop
all "airs;" that is one thing they have to shed,
even as the crab constituent of Hon. Mr. Tull
has to shed his shell, or the snake of the Hon.
Mr. Morris' district has to shed his skin to the
horny part of the eye, if he wishes to thrive.
As for the wealth, may the Hon. Gentlemen
never rise from the table as empty in pocket as
most of us at this time of year. All this shows
one thing, however—it shows that we need to
be a little better acquainted. Let some of our
Hon. Friends pay us, the students, a social call,
and let us show them around. Ask for one of
the editors of the NEWS-LETTER, and we will
make you feel at home. No, gentlemen of the
House and Senate, most of us are good looking, but we are neither haughty of stomach or
proud of purse.

It changes from year to year. Under such
conditions, a fixed policy of management is
impossible. And if success is to last more
than a day, a fixed policy is imperatively demanded.
A business man and athlete should direct
our athletic work just as truly as a business
man and scholar should direct our scholastic
work. He should be consulted, and respectfully consulted, in every matter that in any
way affects our athletic reputation. His
knowledge of business should make his decision final in making games with other
schools, in guarantee terms, in transportation
of teams, and in all the insignificant details
which are likely to become elephants,
and swallow up all that has been "subscribed."
His knowledge of athletics should make his
authority final in the planning of games,
meets, and schedules. His knowledge of people would enable him to stimulate the men
and keep them at the work which his business
and athletic sense projected. His active supervision should be continuous, not the "tenminutes-between periods" spasm of the undergraduate, nor the occasional hour snatched
from a law or medical practice by an industrious, but willing alumnus. It should employ his full time. He should be at the work
all day, and all night, when necessary. His
scope of action should be as wide as the field
to be won. He should be accountable to no
authority except the just authority of the faculty ; and should defer to no one except to
such a representative of the faculty as we now
have in Dr. Renouf.
The employment of such a man with such
powers would not at all change our present
system of athletic government. On the contrary it would make profitable much hard and
earnest work now wasted. Such an officer
would be an invaluable advisor to the Governing Board of the General Athletic Association.
He would be a confidant of managers of teams.
And he would co-operate with coaches to support the authority of captains. Without interfering with the coaches, he could assist them ;
and the authoritative rebuke of one up to
whom they look would be far more effective to
backsliding men than the feeble complainings

of team officials whose desire for popularity
will not permit them to be disagreeable.
"These statements are but theoretical," you
may say. We admit it. However, at the
same time, the theories are not discoveries.
They have been deduced from the success and
failure of many places. And our conclusion
is justified by facts at every point. The University of Chicago, in a few years, is risen from
an athletic nonenity to be the athletic center of
the west. Mr. F. A. Stagg is in charge of its
athletics, and he wields the powers we have described. In some great eastern colleges,
much of the athletic supervision is in charge of
alumni ; but these are not one-hour men.
They are men who have taken root in their
positions until they have formed a whole corps
of such officers as we have described. Pennsylvania has its Faries and Murphy. Yale has
its Seaver Cook and Camp. Princeton has
its Goldie Fine. We may never be as great
